nodes.text: Aggregate production efficiency is desirable in a wide variety of circumstances when taxes are set at the optimal level, even if lump-sum taxation is infeasible
Maximizing social welfare should be done using both taxes (commodity and income) and public production as control variables because lump-sum transfers are generally infeasible
Even when a full Pareto optimum is unattainable (no lump-sum taxes), optimal commodity taxes can improve income distribution and can make aggregate production efficiency desirable

In the optimum with commodity taxes but no lump-sum taxes, marginal rates of substitution need not equal marginal rates of transformation, yet aggregate production efficiency still obtains under optimal taxation
Approach: analyze a one-consumer two-commodity model geometrically and algebraically (prices as controls), derive first-order conditions, then extend to many-consumer case and give rigorous theorems
Geometric result (one-consumer): the welfare-maximizing consumption plan is on the production possibility frontier (offer curve intersects frontier) so production is on frontier rather than interior

Algebraic/calculus method: set consumer prices q and producer prices p as controls, form Lagrangian for welfare v(q) subject to production constraint and equilibrium, derive FOCs including Vk - lambda sum_i p_i (partial x_i/partial q_k)=0 and lambda(f_k - g_k)=0
Result from FOCs: if Lagrange multiplier lambda is nonzero, then marginal rates of transformation in public and private production are equal (f_k = g_k), implying aggregate production efficiency

Characterization of optimal tax structure: when welfare is individualistic, first-order conditions imply proportionality condition x_k^{-1} (partial t_i x_i / partial t_k) is constant across commodities (Ramsey-type rule; equation analogous to 23)

Many-consumer extension: expressing welfare as an indirect function V(q) of consumer prices and assuming continuity and mild preference conditions, the efficiency result carries over provided a further mild assumption excludes unconstrained local maxima

Counterexamples/evidence: constructed examples show optima can lie in interior of production set (weak inefficiency) under special preference/endowment configurations, so efficiency is not automatic without stated assumptions

Rigorous theorems: under assumptions on consumption sets, continuity, convexity, production set closedness and boundedness (assumptions a.1-a.4, b.2-b.4, c.1), an optimum exists and the attainable set is nonempty and bounded (Theorems 1-3)

Conclusion: if the government can tax all commodity transactions (and a poll tax/subsidy is possible), then at the social-welfare-maximizing allocation production is weakly (and typically strictly) efficient and production sectors should be organized to achieve aggregate production efficiency

Extension: intermediate-good taxes are undesirable under constant returns and price-taking private producers because taxing intermediate transactions prevents aggregate efficiency and revenue can be raised equivalently by taxing final goods

Further extensions: international trade, migration, consumption externalities, and capital market imperfections change the derivatives and optimal tax formulas but do not overturn the core efficiency result if reactions and aggregate demand remain well-defined

Limitation: crucial assumptions include constant returns and competitive private sector (no profits), availability of comprehensive commodity taxes (and possibly poll subsidies), continuity and convexity of preferences; violations can invalidate the efficiency conclusions
